item.title: Visualization Practice
item.description: library(Lahman) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2) library(ggiraph) First to Wrangel Data Batting%>% group_by(playerID)%>% summarize(Career_HR=sum(HR),Career_SO=sum(SO))%>% filter(Career_HR>=400)->df Now an Inner Join HR_vs_SO<-inner_join(df,Master,by=c("playerID"))%>% select(nameFirst,nameLast,Career_HR,Career_SO) ———————————————————————————- Next to make it a visualization g<-ggplot()+ geom_point(data=HR_vs_SO, aes(x=Career_SO,y=Career_HR)) + ggtitle("Career Homeruns vs. Strikeouts for Great Hitters") + xlab("Strikeouts") + ylab("Homeruns") g Now to make it interactive

item.title: Normal Distribution
item.description: R Markdown The normal distribution is an extremely important concept for statistics. The assumption of a normal distribution is the only thing that allows for a number of statistical techniques, such as linear regression. The greater the number of observations, the more likely the distribution will look normal. For example a varible with only 30 observations looks a little off: plot(density(rnorm(30))) The plot above looks a little off. It seems a little skewed to the right.
